summary.p: Frey regrets the death of [Diethelm Röist]. He wishes his successor [Hans Rudolf] Lavater all the best and the spirit of David. - At the behest of his father, the surgeon and string player Dietrich from Freiburg [i. Üe.] is increasingly turning to the military. - After reading Luther's [„Kurtz Bekentnis“], the dispute in Bern has somewhat subsided. Frey also hopes to be able to read this writing in order to better understand the response being prepared by the people of Zurich. - He inquires about the ancient coin with the image of an emperor that he had sent to Bullinger. - The recipients of French pensions are worried because of [Johannes] Aal, as they fear they will have to forgo his sermons. - The old man from Freiburg [...] has died unexpectedly. - The mercenaries from Biel had to promise to comply with their city council in the future. - New Year's gift for Bullinger's children. - A shilling for the [maid] Brigitta [Brida Schmid]. - Greetings to Johannes [Diethelm] Keller and his wife [...].

div.p: Greetings. If you are well, most esteemed father, it is good; I am indeed well with my family.

I sincerely grieve that you have lost your consul, who was greatly deserving in matters of the Christian religion and the Swiss republic. However, I congratulate all the pious that Lavater has succeeded him. May the Lord grant him the heart of David and other pious leaders and a long life!

Our Theodoric, that surgeon and string player from Freiburg, has been unhappily absorbed by the military, into which he was sent by his father. I hear that the people of Bern are somewhat coming to their senses after reading Luther's insane pamphlet, which I also hope to read, if possible, so that I may better understand the response, which they say you are preparing, when I can obtain it.

I sent you perhaps a month and a half ago an ancient bronze coin bearing the image of a certain emperor, if I am not mistaken, equaling the size of half a teston. I am uncertain whether you have received it, nor do I know if you have returned it. I would like you to inform me about this matter.

I have nothing new to write about. The royal pensioners are very hostile; they no longer expect any of his sermons. That veteran from Freiburg, joyful in the evening, recently passed away during the night. Our soldiers, all punished to a man, were forced to swear that they would no longer go into military service without the knowledge and against the will of the magistrates.

I send here, as is my custom, these small tokens of my esteem to your children. Our people greet you. Greet your wife in my name, who is like a mother to me, and your children. Farewell and love me as you always do. January 3, 1545.
You will give a shilling to Brigitta.
Also greet in my name Mr. Johannes Keller and his wife.
To the most learned and pious Antistes of the Zurich church, Mr. Heinrich Bullinger, always to be greatly respected by his father.
